conclusion: A skydiver jumps from a helicopter hovering at high altitude. The v-t (velocity-time) graph of his vertical movement in the air from the moment he jumps off the aircraft until he lands is shown in the figure.
From the graph, the sky-diver’s speed at t = 10 s is about 20 m s⁻¹ and at t = 15 s is about 10 m s⁻¹.
Over the 5-s interval the curve descends roughly linearly.

premise: The sky-diver’s speed at t = 10 s is about 20 m s⁻¹ and at t = 15 s is about 10 m s⁻¹. Over the 5-s interval the curve descends roughly linearly.
conclusion: Treating that part of the graph as a trapezoid, average speed ≈ (20 m s⁻¹ + 10 m s⁻¹)/2 = 15 m s⁻¹.

premise: Average speed ≈ 15 m s⁻¹, time = 5 s.
conclusion: Distance fallen ≈ (average speed) × (time) = 15 m s⁻¹ × 5 s = 75 m.

premise: The graph falls a little faster than a perfect straight line at first.
conclusion: The true area under the curve is slightly less than that of the ideal trapezoid, so the actual distance is a bit below 75 m.

premise: The actual distance is a bit below 75 m.
conclusion: The distance fallen from 10 s to 15 s is slightly less than 75 m.
